tags: applied navigation, mountain flying, cross country navigation, search and resuce, SARTIME
title: SARTIME (Search and Rescue)

questions.question: What are three methods for filing a flight plan?
What is a SARTIME?
questions.answer: The time when Search and Rescue will be alerted if a pilot has not terminated their flight plan.

questions.question: A SARTIME (does/does not) have to be the time you'll reach the destination aerodrome.
When planning a flight crossing Cook Strait, give an example of a SARTIME that would not be at the destination aerodrome.
questions.answer: A SARTIME for when you expect to reach the other side of the strait.

questions.question: What is important to do if you don't file a SARTIME for the destination aerodrome?
questions.answer: Update the SARTIME once you reach the point you filed for.

questions.question: What is the difference between ETA and SARTIME?
questions.answer: The ETA is the time you expect to arrive at a point. A SARTIME is a nominated time, usually after the ETA, when Search and Rescue will initiate procedures.

questions.question: If your flight is delayed and you no longer expect to terminate the flight plan before the SARTIME, what should you do?
